article.heading: Properties
article.paragraph: Artin's theoremstates that in an alternative algebra thesubalgebragenerated by any two elements isassociative.Schafer (1995) p.29Conversely, any algebra for which this is true is clearly alternative. It follows that expressions involving only two variables can be written without parenthesis unambiguously in an alternative algebra. A generalization of Artin's theorem states that whenever three elementsx,y,zin an alternative algebra associate (i.e.[x,y,z] = 0) the subalgebra generated by those elements is associative.

A corollary of Artin's theorem is that alternative algebras arepower-associative, that is, the subalgebra generated by a single element is associative.Schafer (1995) p.30The converse need not hold: thesedenionsare power-associative but not alternative.
